name: Tacos al Pastor

chef.name: Chef Juan
chef.bio: Chef Juan is a Mexican chef and owner of Pujol in Mexico City, which has been named the best restaurant in Mexico and is frequently ranked among the world's top 50 restaurants. He is known for his innovative use of traditional Mexican ingredients and his commitment to sustainability.

method: 1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).  2. Blend achiote paste, vinegar, orange juice, pineapple juice, garlic, salt, oregano, cumin, and black pepper in a blender until smooth.  3. Marinate pork in the achiote mixture for at least 1 hour, or up to 24 hours.  4. Preheat a grill or grill pan over medium-high heat.  5. Thread pork onto skewers and grill, turning occasionally, until browned and cooked through, about 10 minutes.  6. Remove pork from skewers and chop into small pieces.  7. Warm tortillas in a dry skillet or on the grill for about 30 seconds per side.  8. Serve pork on warm tortillas with diced onion, cilantro, and a squeeze of fresh lime juice.

name: Chiles Rellenos

chef.name: Chef Juan
chef.bio: Chef Juan is a Mexican chef and owner of Pujol in Mexico City, which has been named the best restaurant in Mexico and is frequently ranked among the world's top 50 restaurants. He is known for his innovative use of traditional Mexican ingredients and his commitment to sustainability.

method: 1. Roast the chiles over a gas flame or under the broiler until charred on all sides. Place in a plastic bag to steam for 10 minutes, then peel off the skin. 2. Cut a slit down the side of each chile and remove the seeds. Stuff each chile with cheese, being careful not to overstuff. In a bowl, whisk the egg whites until stiff peaks form. In another bowl, whisk the egg yolks until pale yellow. Gently fold the yolks into the whites until just combined. Heat 2 inches of oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Dip the stuffed chiles into the egg mixture, letting any excess drip off. Fry the chiles in the hot oil until golden brown on both sides. Drain on paper towels and serve hot with tomato sauce or salsa.

name: Enchiladas Verdes

chef.name: Chef Maria
chef.bio: Chef Maria is a Mexican chef and owner of Dulce Patria in Mexico City, which is known for its modern take on traditional Mexican cuisine. She is also a cookbook author and has been recognized by the Latin America's 50 Best Restaurants list.

method: 1. Preheat the oven to 375°F. 2. Heat the vegetable oil in a skillet over medium heat. 3. Soften each tortilla in the oil for about 30 seconds on each side. 4. Fill each tortilla with a couple of tablespoons of the chicken and roll up. 5. Place the enchiladas in a baking dish. 6. Pour the salsa verde over the enchiladas. 7. Bake for 15 minutes. 8. Top with sour cream, queso fresco, onion, and cilantro.

name: Chicken Enchiladas

chef.name: Chef Maria
chef.bio: Chef Maria is a Mexican chef and owner of Dulce Patria in Mexico City, which is known for its modern take on traditional Mexican cuisine. She is also a cookbook author and has been recognized by the Latin America's 50 Best Restaurants list.

method: Preheat oven to 190°C (170°C fan) and lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish. In a large pot, cover the chicken breasts with water and bring to a boil. Simmer for 15 to 20 minutes or until cooked through. Shred the chicken with two forks and season with salt and pepper. In a small saucepan, heat the enchilada sauce over low heat. Dip each tortilla in the sauce and place on a plate. Spoon some chicken and cheese over the center of each tortilla and roll up. Place the enchiladas seam-side down in the prepared baking dish. Pour the remaining sauce over the enchiladas and sprinkle with more cheese. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes or until bubbly and golden. Serve with sour cream, green onions and olives if desired.

name: Beef Tacos

chef.name: Chef Miguel
chef.bio: Chef Miguel is a Mexican chef and owner of Quintonil in Mexico City, which has been ranked among the world's top 10 restaurants. He is known for his use of local, seasonal ingredients and his commitment to sustainability.

method: In a large skillet, cook the ground beef over medium-high heat, breaking it up with a spatula, until browned and cooked through. Drain the excess fat. Add the taco seasoning and water and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Heat the taco shells in the oven or microwave according to package directions. Fill each shell with some beef mixture and top with lettuce, tomato, cheese, salsa and sour cream as desired.

name: Guacamole

chef.name: Chef Miguel
chef.bio: Chef Miguel is a Mexican chef and owner of Quintonil in Mexico City, which has been ranked among the world's top 10 restaurants. He is known for his use of local, seasonal ingredients and his commitment to sustainability.

method: Cut the avocados in half and remove the pits. Scoop out the flesh and place it in a large bowl. Mash with a fork until chunky. Add the lime juice, onion, jalapeño, cilantro and salt and mix well. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Serve with tortilla chips or as a dip for vegetables.

name: Quesadillas

chef.name: Chef Micheal
chef.bio: Chef Micheal is a Mexican chef and owner of Rosetta in Mexico City, which is known for its Italian-inspired cuisine. She is also a cookbook author and has been recognized by the Latin America's 50 Best Restaurants list.

method: Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and spray with cooking spray. Place one tortilla on the skillet and sprinkle half of it with cheese. You can also add some cooked chicken or beef, black beans and corn if you like. Fold the other half of the tortilla over the cheese and press lightly to seal. Cook for about 2 minutes per side or until golden and crisp. Repeat with the remaining tortillas and cheese. Cut into wedges and serve with salsa and sour cream.

chef.name: Chef Micheal
chef.bio: Chef Micheal is a Mexican chef and owner of Rosetta in Mexico City, which is known for its Italian-inspired cuisine. She is also a cookbook author and has been recognized by the Latin America's 50 Best Restaurants list.

name: Classic Lasagna
method: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). In a Dutch oven, cook sausage, ground beef, onion, and garlic over medium heat until well browned. Stir in crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, tomato sauce, and water. Season with sugar, basil, fennel seeds, Italian seasoning, 1 tablespoon salt, pepper, and 2 tablespoons parsley. Simmer, covered, for about 1 1/2 hours, stirring occasionally. Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Cook lasagna noodles in boiling water for 8 to 10 minutes. Drain noodles, and rinse with cold water. In a mixing bowl, combine ricotta cheese with egg, remaining parsley, and 1/2 teaspoon salt. To assemble, spread 1 1/2 cups of meat sauce in the bottom of a 9x13 inch baking dish. Arrange 6 noodles lengthwise over meat sauce. Spread with one half of the ricotta cheese mixture. Top with a third of mozzarella cheese slices. Spoon 1 1/2 cups meat sauce over mozzarella, and sprinkle with 1/4 cup Parmesan cheese. Repeat layers, and top with remaining mozzarella and Parmesan cheese. Cover with foil: to prevent sticking, either spray foil with cooking spray, or make sure the foil does not touch the cheese. Bake in preheated oven for 25 minutes. Remove foil, and bake an additional 25 minutes. Cool for 15 minutes before serving.

name: Chicken Alfredo

chef.name: Chef Roberto
chef.bio: Chef Roberto is a Mexican chef and owner of Contramar in Mexico City and Cala in San Francisco. She is known for her use of sustainable seafood and her commitment to social justice issues.

ingredients: 2 cups cooked, shredded chicken breast meat
method: 1. Cook pasta according to package directions. Drain and set aside. 2. While the pasta is cooking, season chicken breasts with salt and pepper.  3. In a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken and cook until browned and cooked through, about 6-8 minutes per side. Remove chicken from skillet and set aside. 4. In the same skillet, melt butter over medium heat. Add minced garlic and cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant. 5. Whisk in heavy cream and chicken broth. Bring to a simmer and cook for 5-7 minutes until sauce has thickened. 6. Stir in Parmesan cheese and cooked pasta. Add sliced chicken back to the skillet and stir to combine. 7. Garnish with chopped parsley and additional Parmesan cheese, if desired.

name: Carne Asada Tacos

chef.name: Chef Roberto
chef.bio: Chef Roberto is a Mexican chef and owner of Contramar in Mexico City and Cala in San Francisco. She is known for her use of sustainable seafood and her commitment to social justice issues.

method: 1. Preheat a grill for medium-high heat. 2. In a small bowl, mix together the chili powder, paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper. Rub the steak with the spice mixture on all sides. Grill the steak for 7 to 8 minutes per side, or until it reaches your desired degree of doneness. Remove from the grill and let rest for 5 minutes. While the steak is resting, warm the tortillas on the grill for about 30 seconds per side. Thinly slice the steak across the grain. To assemble the tacos, place a spoonful of guacamole onto each tortilla, followed by a few slices of steak, diced onion, and chopped cilantro. Serve with lime wedges on the side.

name: Carnitas Tacos

chef.name: Chef John
chef.bio: Chef John is a Mexican-American chef based in Los Angeles. He is the executive chef at Casa Oaxaca, which is known for its authentic Oaxacan cuisine. Ruiz has also appeared on the Food Network's Chopped and Cutthroat Kitchen.

ingredients: 2 lbs boneless pork shoulder, cut into 1-2 inch cubes
method: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).  2. Season the pork shoulder with salt and pepper.  3. Heat the oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high heat.  4. Add the pork and cook until browned on all sides, about 5 minutes per side.  5. Transfer the pork to a plate.  6. Add the onions and garlic to the Dutch oven and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.  7. Stir in the cumin and oregano and cook for 1 minute.  8. Return the pork to the Dutch oven and add enough water to cover.  9. Bring to a simmer, then cover and transfer to the oven.  10. Cook until the pork is tender and pulls apart easily with a fork, about 3 hours.  11. Remove the pork from the Dutch oven and shred with two forks.  12. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat.  13. Add the shredded pork and cook until crispy, about 5 minutes.  14. Warm the tortillas on a hot griddle or directly over a gas flame.  15. Serve the pork in the tortillas with desired toppings.

name: Fish Tacos

chef.name: Chef John
chef.bio: Chef John is a Mexican-American chef based in Los Angeles. He is the executive chef at Casa Oaxaca, which is known for its authentic Oaxacan cuisine. Ruiz has also appeared on the Food Network's Chopped and Cutthroat Kitchen.

ingredients: Salt and black pepper to taste
method: 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, cornstarch, baking powder and salt. Whisk in the beer until the batter is smooth and let rest for 10 minutes. 2. In a large skillet, pour enough vegetable oil to come to a depth of 1/2 inch and heat over medium-high heat. 3. Pat the fish dry and cut into 1-inch wide strips. Working in batches, dip the fish into the batter and then add to the hot oil. Fry until golden brown and cooked through, about 2 minutes per side. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. 4. In a small bowl, mix together the sour cream, mayonnaise, lime juice and cilantro. 5. To assemble the tacos, warm the tortillas in a dry skillet or on a griddle. Divide the fish among the tortillas and top with the sliced cabbage, jalapeno and cilantro. Drizzle with the sour cream mixture and hot sauce. 6. Serve immediately, with additional lime wedges and hot sauce on the side.

chef.bio: Chef Juan is a Mexican chef and owner of Pujol in Mexico City, which has been named the best restaurant in Mexico and is frequently ranked among the world's top 50 restaurants. He is known for his innovative use of traditional Mexican ingredients and his commitment to sustainability.
